entry.title: Finishing Things
entry.content:
Well it was pretty busy yesterday, so I didn't get a chance to finish the bash script I started. It's half functional right now, it just adds a new post and creates a really basic header for it. Next step is to have it add to the Makefile.

After that I'd like to automate the make process and git pushing and what not, to make things real easy. I'm sure I can do all that in bash, but maybe Python or Ruby would be good to try. I know I hated on Ruby a little but I do like the language. It's when you're managing like three different versions of Ruby and different sets of gems and other dependancies that things get really gnarly.

entry.title: A New Week
entry.content: Well it's a new week. We'll have to see whether I can remember how to work all these things I set up, or if I get frustrated and just throw it all in the trash. Eh, I'm pretty confident I can make this work.

entry.title: automation
entry.content:
Yesterday and today I've been working on a small bash script to automate adding new posts, it's working pretty well so far I should be able to finish it off today. Just about 20ish lines of bash, nothing fancy.

It's clunky and a little more DIY than what I've worked on lately, but I think that's a good thing, as I'm learning a lot.

entry.title: Authentication and Todo list
entry.content: Well I have things working pretty well here, I think I've figured out why my ssh key wasn't working for git pushes, so this post should work with that. I need to write a small bash script to automate new post creation, as the process is completely manual right now. Just a small thing to create the text file for a post, give it a title and insert it into the Makefile would be great.

entry.title: Hello, World
entry.content:
Testing! This is a new blog post. I decided, for whatever reason, that I wanted to play with some static site generators. I started with Jekyll and Octopress, but those were pretty rickety and fiddly and annoying.

So now I've switched over to the blogc utility, built in C and even more barebones. It was a lot simpler to get it up and running than the Ruby tools even though there were some odd Ruby requirements when compiling. I don't know if this will be a regular thing, but it's been interesting so far.
